President Ronald Reagan: s tax reform in 1986 included a reduction in the business tax rate to 34 percent.
The claim suggests that this tax cut led: thriving middle class, and increased median family income.
The White House cited statistics such as: 2 percent increase in gross domestic product in 1988 and a nearly $2,000 increase in real median household income from 1986 to 1989 to support the claim.
However: experts unanimously agree that attributing the entire economic growth and improvements solely to a single tax cut is not accurate, as there are various other factors and taxes that influence the economy.
